content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools are committed to creating inclusive learning environments where every student—regardless of linguistic background, learning profile, or ability—can access a world-class Cambridge education while meeting Indonesian national requirements.

items: Diversity is an asset: Students with varied backgrounds enrich our learning communities.
All students can learn: With appropriate support, every learner can make meaningful progress.
Early intervention prevents failure: Proactive identification and tiered support systems reduce the need for intensive remediation.
Inclusion is a whole-school responsibility: Every teacher is a teacher of EAL learners and students with diverse needs.

content.text: This philosophy aligns with various standards and laws, including CIS/WASC Standard E, Cambridge Policy B6.2, and Indonesian Law No. 8/2016.

subsections.title: Tier 1: Universal and Quality First Teaching

content.text: All teachers provide Quality First Teaching that meets the needs of 80-85% of students without additional intervention.

items: Differentiation by Content, Process, Product, and Environment.
Universal Design for Learning (UDL) principles to provide multiple means of representation, engagement, and action/expression.

content.text: EAL-Responsive Teaching strategies include pre-teaching academic vocabulary and using sentence frames.

steps.title: Teacher Referral
steps.desc: Teacher completes SST Referral Form documenting specific areas of concern.

steps.title: SST Meeting
steps.desc: Meeting to determine if Tier 2 intervention is needed.

steps.title: Intervention Begins
steps.desc: Intervention starts within 1 week of parent notification.

items: Small Group Literacy Intervention for Grades 1-8.
Numeracy Support Groups for Grades 1-8.
EAL Tier 2 Support for CEFR A2-B1 level students.
Social-Emotional/Behavioral Support.

subsections.title: English as an Additional Language (EAL) Support

content.text: EAL support is integrated into the curriculum to help students develop academic English proficiency.

items: EAL Proficiency Framework aligned to CEFR.
Initial Placement and Assessment Process for new students.
Ongoing Progress Monitoring through formative and summative assessments.

content.text: Tier 3 is for students who have made minimal/no progress in Tier 2 despite interventions.

steps.title: Draft Plan
steps.desc: Learning Support Coordinator drafts the IEP/ILP.

steps.title: IEP/ILP Meeting
steps.desc: Meeting to review and finalize the plan.

steps.title: Implementation and Monitoring
steps.desc: Review progress toward goals every 6-8 weeks.

items: Accommodations and Modifications Framework.
Progress Monitoring and Annual Review.

content.text: Cambridge allows access arrangements for students with disabilities or learning differences.

items: Types of Access Arrangements: Extra Time, Reader, Scribe, etc.
Application Process for Access Arrangements.

content.text: Eduversal recognizes the need to support high-ability students who require enrichment.

items: Identification of Gifted and Talented Students.
G&T Support Models including Subject Acceleration and Enrichment Clusters.

subsections.title: Learning Support Team Structure and Roles

content.text: The Learning Support Team is composed of various roles including Learning Support Coordinator, EAL Coordinator, School Counselor, Year Level Coordinators, and Teaching Assistants.

rows: Coordinates MTSS implementation, leads SST meetings, develops IEPs.
Administers EAL assessments, provides direct instruction, monitors progress.
Provides counseling for social-emotional needs, supports behavioral interventions.
Identify students needing support, communicate with parents.
Support implementation of IEP accommodations in classrooms.

subsections.title: Universal Design for Learning (UDL) as Tier 1

content.text: UDL serves as the foundational cornerstone of Eduversal's Multi-Tiered System of Supports.

items: Key principles of UDL: Multiple means of representation, engagement, and action/expression.
UDL strategies for common learning barriers.

content.text: All teachers receive ongoing professional development in inclusive education.

items: New Teacher Induction covering MTSS framework and differentiation basics.
Annual PD sessions on EAL strategies, SEN awareness, and G&T enrichment.

content.text: Parents are partners in supporting their child's learning.

items: Initial identification and concern communication.
SST decision communication.
IEP/ILP meetings with parental involvement.

content.text: All inclusion, EAL, and learning support data is managed through EduNav.

items: Student Profile Module for EAL and SEN data.
SST Module for meeting minutes and progress monitoring.
Assessment Module for EASE benchmark data.

content.text: Eduversal's inclusion practices align with CIS/WASC standards and Indonesian legal compliance.

items: Alignment with CIS/WASC standards for diversity and inclusion.
Indonesian legal compliance regarding educational rights.

content.text: Eduversal schools partner with external specialists for comprehensive SEN support.

items: Educational psychologists for assessments.
Speech-language pathologists for communication disorders.

content.text: Annual program reviews are conducted to assess the effectiveness of inclusion practices.

items: Data sources for evaluation include MTSS tier distribution and intervention effectiveness.
Guiding questions to assess early identification and Tier 1 instruction quality.

Eduversal is committed to building inclusive learning communities through a structured implementation roadmap.

items: Year 1: Foundation building with training and SST establishment.
Years 2-3: Refinement and expansion of intervention strategies.
Year 4+: Sustaining and innovating inclusive practices.

content.text: Schools should compile evidence related to inclusion practices for accreditation.
